text:
Dear Graydon*
Herewith a brief report of my meeting yesterday, June a, from liOO |sx to
3*20 p.m., with Bob Van Duyn.
(This meeting followed visits to St, Louis by Schooley and Skomia, for the
opening of the In-School Writers* Seminar, which seemed off to a fine start with
Stasheff, MoCance, Girling, Stanley, and others, hostessed by Marguerite Fleming
in gracious, well-jblanned fashion.)
The notes herewith are as written at directly after the conference, with slight
changes and additions later.
I was wholly unprepared for the general direction the meeting with Bob Van Duyn
took. After a pleasant lunch with him I began going over with him the (draft)
general form in which the budget request will be submitted, indicated, with outline,
the nature and contents of the report in preparation, which would accompany it
and xk went over the items (which had been worked out with Graydon in my trip to
Tuscaloosa last week) for which to request supplementary funds (Publishing of
Committee reports and other outstanding items to give Kellogg-financed items
equal form and distribution with others; request for Washington agftcx office;
fixe Prestige Series on Americanism (suggested gxxgga&xfUMflaxljdtoj^
(by Van Duyn on phone to lek Ausmus and me, when I was in Tusoaloosa) as good
project to propose; the kinescope for TV (see Hill report following CNO meeting)
training for national organizations; In-School Grant-in-Aid; and the others we
discussed.
Generally Bob wasnâ€™t in a mood to consider or talk about specifics. His
concern was about generalities!
